Xenoblade chronicles x has a very interesting take on this whole concept (more on a philosophical level than biological) the earth is gone, and you are controlling "mimesomes" basically a vessel for raw data to go into, that functions near identical to a flesh body, but all of the minds are raw data, not brains, granted, these are backups of people who could be debated as previously alive (all humans are dead) or as merely living on in a different way. The game covers this pretty well. I just thought it was a neat thing that should be brought up. There are different perspectives that are at play though, the consciousness of an individual being them vs. the actual body being them, at what point is the line crossed, is there even a line? That's all I really wanted to say, the game is a banger, and makes you think about it long after the playthrough is over.

This video reminds me of something I saw off of one of exurb1a's videos. I don't remember the entire thing verbatim, so I'll roughly quote it.

A buddhist monk is talking to a pilot, and asks "Show me the plane." So the pilot points out the different parts of the plane. The fuselage, the ailerons, the rudders, the flaps, the elevators, landing gear, propeller, everything. But the monk isn't satisfied. "These are all well and good, but what part of this is the plane?" I don't remember if the pilot had an answer, but I thought it was an interesting parallel.

To use an analogy with computers, first I have to tell you the difference between regular storage and RAM. RAM can hold the same type of storage as your hard drive, but if you turn off the power. All data in the RAM is lost. This is also why rebooting your computer works to fix random errors. It is an issue in the data that is added to RAM during the session. Anyway, if you the human was a computer. You would be the data stored in RAM. So when the off switch is turned. What is left, 100% of the the computer ironically, is NOT "you".

How can one say such? Because people that get brain damage are often "not themselves" anymore compared to how they acted and behaved before they attained brain damage. This is the famous Ship of Theseus problem. In short, this is a philosophical debate about an old, rotting ship. You replace each rotting plank of wood with a new fresh plank. The philosophical question is at which point the ship stops beings the old rotten one and has become a new improved ship. The problem is that such a line is undefinable, it is nearly impossible to determine when this takes place. WandaVision offered a unique perspective on this issue, that the new ship never stopped being the old ship, that all versions of the old ship are the old ship itself, even if some parts have been replaced.

There's also an entire menagerie of bacterial life in our guts that is not us, but exists in a kind of cooperative state, helping us digest food and communicating with us through various signaling molecules.

The best explanation i came across is from Paul King a neuroscientist who studied at Harvard University

You and your brain are not separate entities that can compete for dominance. Your brain is part of you, and you are part of your brain.

Agency -- the perception of control -- is a complex topic.

From a neuroscience perspective, "you" are a dynamic construct of your brain. Your sense of who you are is a model your brain creates as a strategy to coordinate optimal action.

The perception that you have of causing an action to occur is a by-product of goals generated by your brain that lead to an action plan, which in turn is split into two pathways: in one pathway, the plan leads to motor movements; and in another pathway, the plan leads to expectations of what perceptions will result from the action. If you reach out your hand to shake the hand of another, you expect your outstretched arm to appear in your field of view, and you expect to feel your muscles and arm moving. When these things happen, you are not surprised and you brain attributes the witnessed action to you as the cause. If you failed to see your arm, you would feel shocked and impotent. If you saw your arm move but had no memory of intending anything, you would say it was a spasm of some sort, or that your arm "had a mind of its own".

This does not mean that the mind is "coming along for the ride" as a passive witness to the actions of the brain. The mind is the framework that is the basis for action plan formulation. This framework, maintained and updated by the brain, is the basis for incorporating new information and understanding the world -- a world that happens to include itself.

In the end, the mind is just a higher level of abstraction for understanding the activity of the brain in the same way that a virtual machine (VM) in computer science is a level of abstraction above a physical machine or CPU. Does the virtual machine control the physical machine? Yes, in the sense that program actions in the virtual machine cause the physical machine to do things. Or is it actually that the physical machine controls the virtual, since the CPU is the source of "life" for the VM? Ultimately, neither one controls the other. The physical machine just proceeds according to the rules implied by its structure, and the virtual machine is a higher level of abstraction that is both real and imaginary (virtual) at the same time.

I don't think that I AM just my body. I believe my experiences, memory's, skills, faults, personality makes me. If my brain was put into a different body I would still be Seth (my name) people simply use my body to recognize who's actually behind my face. And what I just said can be used to prove my point even further, you don't say "me" when your reffering to your hand, face, or even whole body, including your brain. I am not a brain, I'm not a body, I am the pattern my brain is made in. Everything that I experience changes my brain in the slightest way, changing the pattern, changing ME. I am just the way my brain is organized. If you organized the cells in my body to make me fat, I would still be Seth, just fat. If you organized the cells in my brain to change my whole personality, I would be a new man in what used to be Seth's body. I would no longer exist, Id've been just replaced by a new organization of cells. People could and would still call me Seth, but people can call me, as I am right now, Jason, or Mark, or Garthalomous. A name is simply an identification. I'm not SETH, I'm a pattern recognized as Seth.

I recall years ago (early in the century--maybe 2003 to 2005?), Miss Lax's family started to sue people, research labs, and universities over her cells. She nor they signed any consent documents allowing anyone to do research with her body. They maintained that since she was black, everyone thought they were justified in the research. Kinda like the U.S government felt justified in the Tuskegee Experiment since the subjects were all black men. I need to look it back up because I thought they were ordered to destroy their samples.

Found it. In 2013 they reached a settlement. The family now owns the control of the HeLa line of cells. In other words, ain't nobody doing research without their permission.

comment_by: Zoey, Blade of the Cringe Lord
comment_text:
I consider "me" to be my consciousness. My consciousness is the result of my brain developing self-awareness and the capacity to store information about itself.

In other words, I am my brain. My heart, lungs, limbs, and even my eyes, are all simply parts of a biological life support system for my brain.

Each individual cell is so far removed from the information it stores that the constant cycle of death and replacement doesn't affect the information.

Yeah, memories fade, but the permanence of my consciousness does not. As long as I can think about myself and remember that I exist, I'm still me.

Death is simply catastrophic failure. My consciousness is the result of my brain functioning. As my brain ceases to function, the ability to think about myself fades.

I don't believe in a soul or an afterlife. I believe that death is the end. As the brain begins to shut down, as the cells start dying en masse, the ability to process and recall information is lost. With it, I am lost.

I am not a soul inhabiting a body, I am a biological computer that grew complex enough to think about itself.

00:39 I am a cell

You're basically asking the hammer / ship question. Replace 1 piece at a time, is it still the same object?

Well I don't think that applies here, because those individual pieces don't make up a whole and we're not made of hundreds of thousands of things (ship reference), we're made up of connections of cells (brains). What makes you unique and an individual is what your life experiences are made up of, and if you rip 1 cell away at a time it would nullify you (consciously). We are our memories and experiences, which is what our brains do. Rip that apart and no it's gone.

Imagine if you lost some painful part of yourself, I imagine many people would wish that was the case, but losing that is losing a part of YOU.

Replace individual cells with other matter, then no. We're still us, as we replace ourselves within 7 years. It's the connections we make in our brain that make us, us. You've shed and poop yourself out for as long as you've been alive.

A better question would be quantum teleportation. Do you die, and another version of you arrive in the universe?

You, person reading this, are the universe experiencing itself.

In this video there was several questions that made me think. And the video didn't give a direct answer to them. So I wrote down my thoughts for other people who are confused:

0:08
"How much of yourself can you remove before you stop being you?"
I think there's no such an amount. The more you remove, the less you are being you.
You wont suddenly become someone or something else. You will be 99% you, 95% you, 90%, 80%, 60%, 40%, 20%, 5%, 1%, 0.001% and when your last cell is removed, 0% (empty space).
So, if I have to give a number, I'd say 1 cell. When you remove 1 cell from you, you are no more you. Because the definition of "you" includes that cell which is now removed.

1:26
"Does this mean that a part of you became a part of another person or is this other body keeping a part of you alive?"
I think the answer will be "both" if we replace the word "you" with "old you" to make things more clear.
The organ is the part of old you and not the part of the old "other body".
Also, it is no more part of the new you and it is the part of the new "other body".
So, it is both part of old you and part of new "other body"
I'm not a native speaker but I think if we don't replace the word "you " with "old you", the answer would be the first option.

1:46
"At which point would they become you?"
While in transfer, both of you no more exist. Because as I explained above, the moment your first cell is transfered, you are no more you.
You are replaced by newly created and different persons. However, at the end, both of you will be recreated. We can abstract this process with the word "teleportation". However I dont think this is technically a teleportation.

Cancer is not a "being" that "wants to survive". It does not comply to the definition of a selfish-gene carrier (organism) , and moreover it is selfish to the point of self-destruction. It is a program-malfunction, a state that, to a great extend, needs to be actively supressed. It could be said that a cancerous cell is reset to the "ancient default state" that has to be adjusted in order to get to multicellular organisms, where the cells are servants of the reproductive cell line.
Thus, cancer reappears again and again but without being inherited, and when it is inherited it is not selected. Perhaps other suppressed states of the past reappear as disease or new evolutionary pathways..

YOU ARE the agreement of co-existance of your "alive" information. It's the sum of all sacrifices and favors among your minor parts (like cells or atoms or DNA). Living things are bound to keep (even contraryly to their will, if they have one) existing. Dead things are just matter that still hasn't been bound to the cycle of life, or has been detached from it. In other words, living matter is alive when, for some sort of pre-existing configuration, arrangement that make it aware of it's purpose to be alive, it is forced to preserve itself and use energy to maintain a cycle until an exterior force destroy the latter. Dead matter is just unaware matter, or, acyclic preservation configuration of matter. Of course, this is an idea regarding uncouncious microscopic life and does not cross the line that divide the basic "surviving life" to an extent of conciousness and mental complexity.
Life would be more like your software rather than the hardware you live in. The only thing that really matters in a computer, at the end of the day, would be the storages, processes, and other data. Even if you change pieces, or replace by "donated organs" you'll still have the "essence" of it.

In fact, this is just a theory, and it's possible that we might never be able to get an aswer for these marvelous questions...

The most common mistake people seem to make regarding this whole topic is trying to identify the self as a thing, rather than an event. We’re like the sun. It’s convenient to refer to the sum as though it were a thing, an object, but to understand it, you need to understand that the sun is a process undergoing constant change.

The self is the emergent process emanating from the complex process being performed by the body. Thus why if the body takes enough damage, you stop, and why losing small parts or exchanging parts, merely contributes to the process being done that is the self.

I would personally say that what we understand as "ourselves" is really just our brains. It's the organ that gives us consciousness, while the other organs just function to keep the brain alive. I like to imagine it like your brain is like a person riding in a mech, and parts of the mech can be removed, and they will still be removed. Certain vital parts of the mech can be removed, and then the part that allows you to be you dies. Essentially our brains are like a person in a mech that is simultaneously feeding the person inside it, keeping them alive, and the mech can lose some parts and still function somewhat properly, although with more difficulty.
I think it's more useful to think about oneself as a action or process rather than an object.

So realistically, there is no you, no me. The idea of the "you" is a useful organizational construct. "You, go hunt for food. You, go pick those berries downstream. You, start a fire". Because we are complex and social animals, at some point we internalized the idea of the "me", but if we somehow survived from birth without ever meeting another person and also for some reason learned language and otherwise developed normally, I'd be willing to bet that the idea of the "me" would have no meaning. You are only you as long as there are others who are not you. With that framework, every question of what is and isn't you is fairly easy to answer, and also useful. So your organs inside of someone else are not you, though you can speak poetically about it if you like. If you exchange one cell at a time with someone else, you're you until others would say you aren't you, since the idea of "you" belongs to others to begin with.

We are desire. We want, we don't want. But where does this desire come from?
A person might dislike squash because they are allergic to it, but only because they get sick. They might enjoy the flavor or texture. Their aversion to squash is because of an experience of vomiting which was not pleasant, so they avoid eating squash.
A person might dislike squash because of its color, flavor or texture, but this could be woven in to their DNA. Maybe their body do not like foods which aren't acidic.
A person might dislike squash because their brother used to throw them at them and they have bad memories of their childhood.
The desire to dislike squash comes from the memories of experiences.
Desire is a thought interpretation of the physical world.
If thought is of the mind, and the mind is of the brain, and we aren't our bodies, but we are desire, then where does the separation take place?
If we are unconscious for surgery and remember nothing, did we stop existing during the surgery?
Is conscious and unconscious a symbolic experience for briefly existing.
Do we exist only when we have a desire in relation to the outcome of an experience?

I think the 'You' (the character/conscious part) is based on how the neurons in your brain are wired. Everybody's brain is quite similar, but the neurons never have the exact same connections to other neurons. You and i are not our kidney, not our bones and not even the proteins of our brain, that is the hardware on which our software is running. If i donate a part of my liver or a kidney, nothing of my software is copied to another person i still remain i, it is just hardware sharing. If i got a third kidney or a second liver it wouldnt change what i am, it were just hardware upgrading. My software is all that what is non material, Informations, my operating system. I got my Desktop(consciousness) my BIOS(subconsciousness and vegetative nervous system), HAL(motoric nervous system), i have my databank(memorys), my metadatabank and construction guidance(DNA). And on this Desktop i can execute all the functions and applications the logic of my OS is be able to, creativity, solving logical problems, communicate, running simulations, doing save and write operations, and so on, even dreaming ist a type of defragmentation and memory management.
I am the summary of all parts of my software + (the + stands for the unknown parts of the software and for parts that dont sum up but multiply or potentize).

If you want to have some sort of definition of what makes you for yourself, can't you just look at what things you can subtract while still considering yourself "gone" and go from there? Like, I'm not my foot, it's a part of me. If I lose it, I wouldn't consider myself not to be me, there's just a physical part missing (and the associated symptoms of that fact). Isn't "what are you" much more tied to brain cells specifically, and the question of consciousness? Cells regenerating and replacing themselves in most of the body (skin, flesh, bones, etc) is a known thing, yet we don't seem to lose sight of who we are from that. And yet, all cells aren't replaced - how brain cells react to old age, and the onset of age-related mental conditions feels like they have a more notable impact on this question, to me.

Philosophic question
Why does the pattern that we observe to be ourselves, have to be made of easy to grasp absolutes, me and you, life and death, right and wrong are surly absolute to us, but how do we know that the fuzzyness we percieve around these matters is not merly a feature of our ability to grasp the pattern that is us in a more complete or complex way. After all, its good to know hot and cold, but better to know cool and warm, and best to know our favorite temperature. Our pattern can easily be somthing of the like. Also notice that we find ourselves less motivated to learn about the universe the less we observe it to confirm any potentially particular pattern. I read(present tense) that as an indication that we find somthing useful about the universe around us, and i think that starts with the belief that the universe around us should conform to some pattern of usefulness for us. Of course we must keep an open mind so we dont get caught up trying to make the universe somthing that its not, because that would make any overall pattern of usefulness in the universe invisible to us.

We are information in motion. More specifically, electric and chemical information conducted in the CNS, mainly in the part known as the brain. Because this information is in a constant flux, this allow intelligent beings such as us to experience the passing of time in a complex and continuous way that a bacteria, for example, cannot; And finally, sentient beings are just intelligent beings that grew smart enough to ask why those things happen.


But exactly HOW it happens is something else. Emergence (if you don't know yet as is cannot be explained as a result of something else, as it is a primordial concept, more like a way to abstract the seemingly random interactions that make life possible, and when stacked in layers over layers result in intelligence and later sentience. Trying to figure what happens in the conscience of a living being in real time and correlate the biological functions with their results is like trying to figure out the meaning of every single bit of a quantum computer program just by looking at the way the circuits work, without ever writing it anywhere. Such a thing is only possible for a being of higher intelligence than the device (human in the case) being analyzed, a feat worth of at least a lesser version of the Laplace's demon.


In other words, the exact work of every human mind in real time is unintelligible, eldritch and unreachable to another human being of equal construction (IQ isn't that much of a difference to ever allow this barrier to be touched). And finally, if we ever manage to give birth to a conscience more intelligent than us, capable of grasping the human mind, we would have to program it to somehow make the information gathered meaningful to us before trying to read it. This piece of information, while extremely useful, only would represent a very limited aspect of the human mind studied, but nonetheless would be much more accurate than any psychoanalyses could ever be.

I think the question posited by this video is kind of silly. You are your brain. The body is essentially an object being controlled by the brain. It has some cool processes that hook up with you (the brain) and keep you alive, but it's not you. You could replace it all with machinery that fulfilled the same purpose if it existed and you'd still be you just in a non biological body. It's really not that complicated. This isn't a ship of Theseus situation because your consciousness isn't spread out across your entire body.

The idea that cells do not contain consciousness is an assumption. At what point do you draw the line at consciousness? Is it when an organism to become self aware? When it is capable of simple feelings? Or is it when something gains the desire to persist? Cells have a desire to persist and CAN feel stimuli. If it senses something attacking it, it will move away because it can feel. To me, saying individual cells do not have consciousness does not make sense. Having multiple cells connect and communicate as one allows such creature to begin interpreting its environment and self/other cells or in other words, THINK. Then you bring in other bodys who can do the same thing and we start interpreting the world together. We're all just a mass consciousness just trying to grow and interpret our existence at this point.

This is a bit misleading. You answered the question "what is a living body?", not "what are you?" (for the entire video the term "you" was used to indicate not only the body but also "the self"). Yes, a lot of cells die and are replaced, but not neurons (simplified). So probably the real answer to the question "what is the self, or conscience?" is to be found in the complex network of electrical impulses between our neurons. Life, and also - probably (I personally don't know much about this topic) - conscience / identity / the mind, is an emergent property: something that a complex system has, but not the single parts that form it.
So, you totally missed the point, or you just chose a wrong title.
But the premise was there! It's just a pity you didn't delve into the topic (I don't know if there is another video about this) (the second part about split brains is not the answer, and I think it's misleading as well).

Basically the short answer to "what are you?", body-wise (since that was the approach of this video), would be "your brain". How much of your body can be taken away before you cease to be "you"? Well, all of it, except your brain. If you could be amputated from the neck down and still be kept alive, you would still be "you".

You also used the term "genetic code" improperly: there's only one genetic code (correspondence between groups of three nucleotides to one aminoacid). Of course the genetic material of a cell can differ from another one in the same individual, as you said. The genetic code remains the same.

Anyway, the video is really inspiring and make people think about this topics. So thank you for your work!

I believe we are essentially a process, a program running in a machine. We are a continuously running consciousness perpetuated by a self-repairing body. We aren't our cells, we aren't the matter. We are the net result of the systems of the body working together, and as long as that process isn't interrupted, we stay around. This makes sense to me because it's the only unique thing I can point to. It can't be our exact configuration, because you could theoretically clone that (see Star Trek transporters). It's also why you could theoretically transfer yourself out of the flesh body... maybe. Here's how I think you could do it.

If your brain can contain you, then it can still contain you if you lose one brain cell. You lose brain cells all the time. So, you could replace that one brain cell, with a synthetic replica or equivalent. Do that, and you're still you. That means you could replace another brain cell, then another. There's no one point where it makes sense to say that you stop existing, and a clone starts existing. It's a similar form of replacement to what we experience constantly, yet we still exist. Therefore, you could replace every cell in your body with something else and still be you, as long as the mental process of "you" doesn't stop. Don't think of this like the Ship of Theseus, at best the ship would be your body, not you. The ship is not conscious, it does not have a "self". The analogy doesn't really work. This video, and a lot of stuff I hear about the sense of self, has a very Ship of Theseus way of thinking. It's interesting and important, because that logic what made me come to my conclusion about us as a constantly running program.

I would say you are always yourself no matter how many cells you lose.
Say for example a institution for teachers. A teacher teaches students who grow to become teachers that teach other students that become teachers. Similar with cells, the dying cells “ teach “ the new ones how to “be” a cell in this particular body. The role of the dying cell is replaced by the new cell who will teach the cell that replaced the dying one how to be that cell. So, no matter what happens, all the cells in your body “know” how to be you as a whole, and thus, you are always you.

How do they know that individual cells aren't intelligent? Like, take a neuron. Those things are as complicated as large cities, with all sorts of different structures at all sorts of different scales, and with loads of very complex interscale and intrascale interactions occurring throughout, and which also interact with neighboring neurons via synapses.

Think about it. The more we look at nature, the more we find how many non-human organisms are also intelligent. Whales, elephants, octopi, crows, spiders, and ant colonies all exhibit intelligent, adaptive behavior, and they're widely spaced on the evolutionary tree. What about amoeba? Plants? Fungal colonies? They are all living things that emerge out of the interactions of smaller components. Who's to say that the components don't possess some kind of intelligence themselves?

So what you are asking is; what is the material base for the idea of "you". But although our existance is completely dependant on material requirements, the self is an "experience", derived from matter sure, but not equivalenbt to matter. I think we should view this "experience" as another phenomena of existance other then matter (although one is dependant on the other). So, can we then say that we actually experience a "you", a "me", a constant self? In the breif moment I dare say yes, but over time, the experience of who we are seems to shift and change. But maybe we can say that we have a constant identity, even though the self is changing, just like a plant is small at first and then grows up to be a big tree. It is clearly changing all the time, but do we say that the change occurs to a single entity, or that something entirely new is born at every given moment? For the sake of our sanity, maybe we must have a concept of eternal but changing self.

Just throwing it out there.

I've always held to the concept that the "self" is an emergent property of your overall existence. So long as the primary part of your body that maintains the "self" is intact, most notably the brain, "you" will remain you no matter how much you replace. The continuity of self is the most important function of this equation. Obviously, there are many factors that contribute to your state of mind, but assuming replacement parts can emulate those properties, "you" will continue to exist. As technology advances, even portions of the brain will be replaceable.

I know this is super old, and probably no one is actually reading these comments. BUT, if someone interested is still reading these: y'all should definitely check out cybernetics-systems theory! 'The Tree of Knowledge' by Maturana and Varela is a classic in the field (which I think has now largely turned into information theory/informatics?) and very accessible. It's ultimately not a theory/framework that I personally utilize, but really fascinating and thought provoking none-the-less. It's also a pretty solid example of "natural" sciences doing "social" science well. Which... well... I mean... look, I really enjoy you all's videos, but man the social scientist in me cringes when you approach those topics. There are such nuanced, interesting, and sometimes very weird AND thought provoking (in the same way quantum physics, or existential threats can be) approaches out there, and I know y'all would do a great job of engaging and explaining them in fun ways!

We tend to think in categories of time and space. I'm a part os space existing now. But Einstein showed that there's really not something called a space and separately something called a time, but ther's a single entity called space-time. In this space-time, any object is not a collection of space points in a certain point in time, but rather a collection of space-time points, called events. So a person is not something existing now. Rather, it is a collection of points in space-time, a 4-dimmensional physical process. So in that sense, as much as we can simplify time to talk about past, now and future, a person doesn't only exist in the present, it is the collection of all the past, present and future "versions" of that person.

Also, this video forgot to mention we kind of know that each human has a distinct collection of cells that make it that person (in the sense, that they make that human different than any other human), which is the nervous system composed of a variety of cells (like neurons), which stores a collection of information that produces a pattern of information processing know as you, and we also know that this information is encoded in constant flow of bio-electric signals in the nervous system.

This video is philosophically very unsophisticated. You are you as long as you have consciousness. If I cut off your arm you are still you because your arm has nothing to do with consciousness. If your brain dies, there is no more you because you are not conscious anymore. If you fall into a comma or are sleeping, you are still you because you subconscious is still active. You are just not aware of it. If your subconscious also dies, then there is no more you. You are completely dead. Others (your family for example) will still recognize your body as you because its just convenient from a language perspective and it IS true that it was the last place 'you' existed. Biology and physics have nothing to do with "you" as a concept. Only consciousness and subconsciousness are. You can become a full cyborg if you wish to or do that weird cell by cell exchange, but as long as your consciousness and/or subconsciousness remain the same, you are still you. You don't use science to answer philosophical questions because science at its core is based on philosophy (just like everything else we do as humans). Science can help us understand those concepts better and how they apply to reality, but that is not how we make a new philosophy and explain it. Philosophy explains itself. Science builds what philosophy has, further.

WARNING: Reading this might cause an existential crisis!



"I" am not defined by my cells, in that case, I'd be a new person all the time, which is wrong, as I know I was, am and will be the same person throughout my life, with the differences being what I look like, how I think and what I know.

"I" am not defined by my body, as every part of it can get replaced, just like the cells, which again means that a cyborg would not be who they used to be, and by extension, that would mean cyborgs are replacements of someone who doesn't live anymore, which by the way, is very creepy.

This is why not only me but most people think that "they" and "me" are defined by our brains. This almost makes sense, but would that mean that if a brain were to be exactly replicated, the person in that brain would control two brains?

What I am trying to say is that most ways to define who someone is, do have flaws. And one flaw that is consistent through most of them is this:
If there were to be an exact copy of someone, either that person would be controlling both bodies with the same mind, or they would be different persons, but with the same looks, thinking process and memory. If the second possibility is the case, then that would mean that if those two copies of each other experience anything, anything at all, different from each other, if they began looking differently, thinking differently and/or knowing different stuff, they would not be copies anymore. They would be like any normal one-egged twins. Similar, but not the same person.

The only way to define a person without this flaw would be to define them by their consciousness, or their "soul".

And this is where it becomes unclear and merely just speculations.
We don't know what consciousness is. We just know that it is what defines us.
Our consciousness, soul, what makes us ourselves, is just something that can't be changed. If it could be changed, it wouldn't feel like we're the same person as we used to be before.

Since we don't know what consciousness is, that means we're still no further in explaining who we are than what those who believe in souls and reincarnation were/are.

Because if consciousness truly cannot be changed, is what defines us, and not our memories, cells or thinking methods, that means we can and most likely will be reincarnated in some way. If we were reincarnated, we wouldn't remember our past lives at all. It would be as if we weren't reincarnated. The only difference would be that it wouldn't be completely nothing after death. Surely, we would never know that we will ever live again or that we've lived before, but it's still better than nothing, right?


PS: Now that I've reread this for myself, I think I should have a warning for a potential existential crisis...

This video didn’t even attempt to answer the question it posed. We aren’t defined by our cells or our DNA, although modern society tries hard to define us this way. Instead, we are defined by the hideously complex and entirely unique arrangement of neurons within our brain. However, that definition changes based on the ‘host’ that lugs us around from day to day. Imagine your mind was suddenly inside the worlds most beautiful person; your perception of yourself and that of others would be changed, and thus your definition would change too.

It’s a question of psychology, not physiology.

So consciousness is the principle that allows something to understand itself and question its own existence. In an attempt to search for meaning in existence, humanity creates ideas such as the spirit and religion which provides comfort and satisfies some people's lust for meaning. But religion isn't right. We have disproved religion using science, which we believe is truthful. Those of us who subscribe to the ideas of science are then left with a meaning-shaped hole in their existence. Science doesn't provide meaning, which means the truth is that meaning is a false hope. Creatures that question their own existence question the idea of life, and what it actually means to live. But living organisms are just, as this video explains, collections of systems which are controlled by firing neurons. But the neurons aren't controlled by anything. Neurons fire without any signal or action causing them to happen. In essence, they are entirely random. These neurons are what consciousness is comprised of, and since consciousness is the idea of control over an organism's entire being, and since consciousness is created by a random process, does that mean complete consciousness in a living organism such as humanity is a paradox? Life contradicts consciousness and so the two can't coincide, so it must be a paradox, right? So we are not entirely conscious because if we were, we would not be biological organisms.

I would argue that we are in fact the process itself and the items which are the collective which we are.

So, my home is me. All that I interact with that allow me to exist as I do now are me. What people sympathize with and believe in changes what they shall do, and makes the process that is them sustain itself differently, therefore, that is a part of them as well.

This is a rather fuzzy way to think about it, but the way I see it is the most accurate way to do so. Because, as stated in the video, each part of us does not exist indefinitely, and eventually dies off in its own accord. But the process itself continues. Cells, thoughts, circumstance; all of these things change on their own accord, but during this people still manage to identify as themselves. Therefore, all of these things are them. And yes, our state of being and identity is just a snapshot, and just an arbitrary way of comprehending ourselves with no truth to it inherently.

I think the concept of self originates from, and asked by, the human mind which is biased by default. For example, the fundamental construction of knowledge is story driven. When philosophers attempt to define "what is self?", The answers that seem to make sense to us the most is the self that is part of our narriative story through some dimension(like time or space). I think the concept of self, if there is such a thing, is conceptually beyond the construction of a story. Therefore humans cannot understand the true nature of this concept. For example, quantum physics is naturally very difficult to grasp as a concept, same with 13 dimension movements. I think the question of self is even harder to grasp than those 2 because it is further away from how human knowledge is constructed.

If my ideas are true, it will mean that there are certain knowledge that humans cannot comprehend.

I find this to be one of the most profoundly magical things about the universe. We are made up of billions of little lives, being born, working together, living, and then dying, and yet our sense of self remains intact, even when we eventually have all of our individual cells replaced. There is some kind of other part of us that doesn’t seem to be entirely dependent upon the individual material parts. We are literally greater than the sum of our parts. What if that is ultimately what has been thought of as God, Goddess, or the Supreme Being? What if we are the cells that make up the universe? What if the universe is alive?

This video kind of reminds me of a paradox. Theseus’s ship

Say you own a boat, but have to keep replacing parts. At one point, you replace every single piece of the boat, but you kept all of the old parts. If you built a ship out of all the old parts of the ship, which one would be the original ship? The one made of replaced parts, or the one made of the original parts? This kind of relates to the whole beginning hing at the episode, when it said, “how much of your body could you replace, and still be ‘you’?”

Sooooo, cells are machines. Consciousness is what you are really questioning here. Brain is cells, just many little machines with separate specialized functions, group functions, and part of a greater total machine, but all machinery nonetheless. So what is consciousness? It is what "actually feels" and actually "likes" or "dislikes" what it feels. Thinking and calculating, well, that is mysterious. The human brain can do that, as can a very sophisticated computer. but even the most sophisticated computer is just a machine, and not really "feeling" nor really "liking" or "disliking," not really "feeling" pleasure or pain, and so not really "conscious." So we are striving to create "artificial intelligence," but we cannot create "artificial consciousness." Consciousness is what the universe -- what exists -- IS. All this other stuff, including rocks and cells, that other stuff is just serving consciousness, or harboring consciousness.

The consciousness has a goal, I think, to feel more pleasure and less pain, more joy, less sorrow, to have more "liking" than "disliking." Why we need bodies to have pleasure, joy, and liking is a question, and without pain, sorrow, and disliking, could we have pleasure, joy, and liking??? Must there be a contrasting opposite for what it is we want to exist? Something to think about.

I see identity as more of a psychological matter. In my eyes, my body doesn't make me, my body holds me. Say, for example, we figured out how to transfer my consciousness onto a computer, but I would no longer in my body. In that case, I'm not dead, as I'm in the computer. The body holding me, however, is dead. It's sort of the way people think of cells, but rather than being another form of matter or some supernatural object that we cannot comprehend, but, rather, it is the set of reactions that generate my thoughts. which creates my consciousness. (All of this, by the way, is assuming a consciousness can be made through reactions, and souls do not exist.) So, even if all of organs are switched with all of another person's organs, I am still in the body where my consciousness resides.

This is why i am different than i was when i was a kid because i have many new pathways now than before and have learned many new things, so i behave differently and have a different personality than when i was 7 and probably will be different when im 70. However a lot of the brain patterns are the same and memories are there so i can remember what it was like when i was 7. Its all just to do with the neural networks, they are what make us different. You're ego is an illusion, it is all just brain networks firing and this firing is being controlled by the laws of physics.

Around 0:50, why should cells have no purpose? They might not have purpose in the sense of 'I want to achieve this or that' but photoreceptors certainly have the purpose to translate photons into chemical signals (glutamate, or rather: lack thereof). Same for macrophages or sperm or any other type of cell...

Around 1:40, if you exchange one cell at a time with someone else, there will be a moment from which on you are no longer 'you': The moment your brain cells are exchanged. Or rather, it depends whether the exchanged brain cells are inserted into your brain with exactly the same connections that you old cells had.

'You' are not your organs or cells (those are just machinery). 'You' are the connections that your brain cells have formed over the course of your life. If you change those connections (which we can't do artificially in the sense of plug and play), you become someone else. Maybe you are a very optimistic person right now, but if you change brain cell connections at the right places, you would become a pessimist, or a murderer or a genius. 'You' are the neural network that your brain formed according to everything you experienced in life. If you experience only bad things, it is very hard to stay a 'good' (from society's view) person and vice versa.

Also, if your brain cell connections are what makes you 'you', it means that when you die, you are gone forever and will never come back unless, by chance, some other human forms exactly the same brain cell connections that you had, which is (even at 7 billion people and more coming) statistically pretty much impossible.

To me, the easy answer is that you are whatever parts of your brain support your conscious mind. I mean what would you most want to protect? But if your conscious mind survived while everything else died, you would continue to be "you". At the same time. I don't think transferring the information about your brain into another information processing system would transfer "you" over as well. I believe that a person's unique conscious experience is supported by the brain matter they currently have. Replicating their information over to another system, like a computer would just give the computer an identicall conscious experience. This view is scientifically informed, but not written from a scientific standpoint-more of an egocentric view that favors consciousness, as the aversion to ceasing to be conscious is basically synonymous with the aversion of death.

Henrietta Lacks was a black woman who had her tissue removed and studied without her consent or knowledge for decades before her family and children had even heard about it. It's mildly disturbing that it took sixty years for someone to say, "Hey, maybe we should ask permission from people for this kind of usage of their genome and tissue samples?", but at least at this point, Henrietta's name will be credited, and her family will have a say in how HeLa cells are used. https://www.nature.com/news/deal-done-over-hela-cell-line-1.13511

Really curious what the people that disliked this video have to say as to what's wrong with it.

As the video stated, this topic leaves science and enters philosophy. This has been a long standing philosophical question usually know as Ship of Theseus. The original question was: if you gradually replace every part of a ship, is it still the same ship?
Heraclitus was also perceptive enough, depsite not having the knowledge of modern science, to suggest that since we're perpetually chaning, we don't actually have identities. "You can never enter the same river, since the water is always moving". Thus he said that "nothing is, but everything is becoming." One of his students, who's name escapes my memory at the moment, went even furhter and jokingly said that since names are attached to identity and we have no lasting identity, we shouldn't even name things, but simply point in them. (Kind of reminds me of that passage from '100 Years of Solitude' when Marquez writes: "It was back in the days when a lot of things weren't named yet and we had to point at everything").
Another philosophical reference I rememebr is that of Marcus Aurelius in his "Meditations" who takes the view expressed in the video around 05:27, that since we all share the same elements and atoms (which at that point was thought to be undivisable (the meaning of the word atom) and eternal), our identity remains in them even after our death.
Another view on the subject, also mentioned in the video, is that identity from the very get go was a mistaken concept. This view has been held by certain religions in Eastern Asia, such as certain types of Buddhism and Hinduism, and is also thoroughly discussed in Herman Hesse's "Steppenwolf".
My own personal opinion is that identities are simply useful. Somewhat of a pragmatic view. As Bertran Russell said "matter is simply a convenient way of grouping events" so is identity a quite handy tool in order to actually avoid simply pointing at stuff. Alternatively one could say that the illusion of identity, if it is indeed an illusion, is so strong that for us it may as well be true. Once again, this a sort of pragmatism of Peirce and James, but in this insatnce I'm willing to subscribe to it. I am a completely different person, both physically and mentally, from that time when I deposited money into my bank account, but let me pretend for the sake of convenience that I'm the same person, so I can have the money to buy things...

It's simple. I am the cognitive/mathematical structure encoded in my neurons, implemented by the universe using matter. It's not about specific atoms or cells, just like a program is not about the atoms of the processor it's running on. If you pause a simulation of a person, and then send the data to another computer, and then  continue it, the person will continue living and not experience anything during the jump. Your body constantly replaces the base atoms and cells during your life. General anesthesia actually stops your neurons from being able to transmit messages, in effect your brain is paused during the time. It's about the pattern/idea, not the base matter implementing it. Yet another kurzgesagt video marred by sloppy terminology. It consistently uses "genetic code" where it should be using "genome."

The genetic code is common to just about all life on earth and refers to the mapping between nucleotide triplets and amino acids. The genome is unique to every individual (apart from identical twins/clones) and may change over time in some cells of that individual.

"Genetic code" is not a synonym for "genome" and kurzgesagt needs to get things like this right if it expects any credibility.

"You" are defined as a locus of identity.  For example, if I were to buy a new car from the factory, this is an original car.  When I replace gasoline or passengers, it remains the original car and the same car.  When I replace the tires, it is no longer the original car, but due to a locus of identity (the VIN and odometer), it is still considered the "same" car.  I have the car for years and it accumulates wear which slowly changes the car, and still then it is considered the "same" car.  I replace major parts, but not the VIN and odometer, it is still considered the same car.  Then I dismantle my car and transfer 99% of my old car's parts to a new frame with a different VIN and odometer--it is now a "different" car.    The locus of identity for a person is a person's mental faculties, the configuration of nerve cell connections orchestrating their higher behaviors.   A person ages, gains and recovers from injuries, and is considered the "same" person.  But a person who goes through a brain injury, or a set of experiences which significantly alters their personality, and they are often considered a "different" person or "not themselves" to those around them.

What you said about a self-sustaining, ever shifting patterns, as well as gray areas of causes and effect- this same principle can be applied to the universe as a whole. The universe is a vast and amazing and complex thing that constantly shifts and changes from one moment to the next. In fact, quantum physics teaches us that in a sense, all things are gray. A particle can also be a wave. Cause and effect does not necessarily have to be linear. What happened now is not necessarily the only thing that could have happened because of what happened before now. An electron doesn't have to be in one place, it could be in another. Virtually anything is possible, and in another universe, some"where" else, it has already happened. In fact, if you had a silly dream as a child that you never achieved, probability and quantum physics dictates that there is another you who achieved that dream. You may not be the same you that you were yesterday, the universe the same one it was seconds ago, but does it truly matter? Things change. Everything changes. Or, perhaps, everything is remade anew in every moment. Think about it. You could become someone new and different and amazing, and be as true to yourself as you were as a child. You are not a single constant state. You're far too complicated to be seen like that.

There's actually a good reason none of your DNA is "human" and yet YOU are.

Imagine a set of Lego Bricks. None of them are officially "car", or "house" or "building" (LOL XD_), they're just individual blocks. It's only when you make them into a building that they become "building", but they're still just Lego. It's possible to disassemble them and make them into some other building. So which building are they, fundamentally? Well, neither. They're just building blocks. It's the same for DNA.

Cells on their own can't do much, like pieces of a robot. Only when you assemble them do they do anything.

People see a video like this , and don't realize that they are nothing more than an ephemeral conglomeration of subatomic particles that, somehow, through some miraculous and unfathomably complex web of cell interaction, manifests itself as a self-aware and intelligent being, and that being attempts to just simply survive in human form for about 80 years. A gestalted whole that is greater than the sum of it's parts and inherently disconnected from its own true nature. The self, the consciousness, the thing we all refer to as "I", is the result of these extremely fast and complex atomic interactions that are way below our macroscopic intuition. Your beliefs and self-values are not actually real, just confabulations of these atoms I've been referring to that serve as survival tools. Any notion of morality is also not real in this case. In this case, there is no point in devoting your life to these nonexistent ideals other than for the sole purpose of survival. What bugs me is that people can watch a video like this and then just go about their daily lives, and it never even registers in them that they just watched something that should make them reevaluate literally their entire lives. But they don't- they just say "wow, mind blown" and move on. Like wtf? If you're religious, you should use this video to see if the idea of the "soul" can possibly offer a philosophical solution (which it can), and if you're atheistic, you need to come to terms with the fact that you, as you know yourself, are not real. Just a simulation ran by the brain that assists in survival.

Cells connected to your consciousness are you.  Your consciousness is not affected by donating a kidney.  While the kidney does share your DNA, it no longer responds to your body's needs, but rather to the needs of its new host.  You can therefore say that anything that responds to the needs of it host body is part of that body, and if that  body responds to your consciousness, it is you.  Cancer is therefore not you.  Again it shares your DNA, but it does not respond to the needs of its host, which is why it can kill you.

What if we are not actually physical? Not in a religious way, but hear me out.

What if our selves are like memories and programs on a computer, more specifically OS? Programs can be modified, tweaked, etc. Parts in a computer can be swapped out (assuming the hardware can work with the software)(also organ transplants)  and even nonessential programs (memories) can be deleted (forgotten) and the computer still function normally. However, switching operating systems is a huge change. Icons look different, programs have to be made to work with the different OS, etc.

Perhaps we are simply how the cells in our brain send signals to each other.

Just need to point out one extremely misleading part of the video: While yes, the DNA in each of your cells does differ a teeny, tiny bit, (mostly due to random copying errors during mitosis), it's such an absurdly small percentage of your DNA that it's not really worth mentioning.

You share 99.9% of your DNA with every other person on earth and almost 99% percent of your DNA with the chimpanzees at your zoo. Now imagine what pecentage of your DNA you share with close relatives (Likely something like 99.999%). Now imagine how much of your DNA one of your cells shares with another one of your cells and it's probably something like 99.99999999%. The differences between the dna of your cells is so absurdly small that it's not worth mentioning. It's really misleading when you say that your cells don't have basically the same DNA because they absolutely do. 1,000 mutations is actually an incredibly small number compared to the THREE BILLION chances you have for mutations.

For all those that claim they are simply the brain. Please point out to which part of the brain and which subsection? Not sure why the hip thing to do is to deny the soul when its the only concept which fully explains our experience and reality.

We are the soul which uses the brain to experience reality.

Test it out. When you solve 4x7 are you asking your brain to come up with the answer or are you as the brain experience the process required to come up with the answer?

When you drive your car are you experiencing all the inputs required required from your limbs to drive. Or are you letting your brain which controls your body do what it needs to do in order to drive wherever you want?

When we train aren't we simply training our brain to do certain actions in a event. When we learn aren't we simply conditioning our brain to be able to do certain tasks better or gain new information?

Free will can also be tested since there are actions which we don't experience free will with and others in which we have full control and others which can be controlled at times.

For example heart rate cannot be controlled by ourselves. Neither are instincts. They happen without our will. Then you have movement, thoughts, mindsets, which we can clearly control. Then we have breathing which we control at times and at others times it becomes a background task our brain does without our input. I'm sure no one is constantly telling themselves breathe in breathe out.

You are a pattern. You recognize you because the pattern that is your properties remains somewhat consistent from day to day to day. the hypothetical question that, for example, you teleport but the transporter broke so you're still there and then a new "you" shows up brings up ambiguity because the pattern has been perfectly continued again somewhere else, so the pattern is the same and they are both "you". However, the location changed all at once, and you've only ever been a single entity, so is it you now that we've considered the group of "you"? These hypothetical scenarios are problematic and introduce grey area because we have intentionally changed the pattern, but at the same time, assumed in our hypothetical that the pattern must not change because "but it's exactly the same", thus creating the problem ourselves, alike most paradoxes, which are only paradoxes because our language cannot adequately describe them.

What, so are we discussing philosophy now? I might as well give my two cents on the matter.

Personally, I think our conscious existence is the collective result of the neurons in our brain. Kind of like a hive mind, where a singular bee is rather one-note, but an entire hive is a massive factory of honey and more bees, one neuron doesn't amount to much and I'd imagine it'd have barely enough memory to store say a letter of the alphabet, but a whole pile of them form our conscious mind, therefore, us.
I think a bigger question to ask yourself would be: What kind of cosmic force caused us to exist in THIS body in particular? What causes us to stare out of these eyes, move these arms, breathe through this mouth, and think of all this stuff? Or to put it in much shorter words: what the hell am I doing here?
If you want to know more about this you should check out this waitbutwhy is great. http://waitbutwhy.com/2014/12/what-makes-you-you.html

It's the Ship of Theseus paradox, only made more personal, and not quite the ship of Theseus paradox. If you have a ship, and replace the parts one at a time, at what point is the original ship not the original ship? What happens when we take the original ship parts and construct another ship from it? Does that give us two original ships?

But it brings up another interesting question. Where does "us" begin and our "hardware" end? Are we our nerve cells, our cancer cells? To answer the question, try this simple mind experiment. Say I uploaded my mind to a computer. The computer is running a perfect (not flawed) copy of my mind. Let's say that in the process of uploading, my human body is completely destroyed.

Would I still be me in that scenario? There is nothing even of the original left.

Personally, I think I would be me in that scenario. So, I contend that we are a group of beliefs, feelings, and reactions that constitute the way we react to other people in the world. But that's just me...

Almost all of the questions inside this video don't make sense. Like, at the basic core of the question, it assumes that by dividing someone up, we somehow have two "pieces" of our bodies. In reality, "we" as a body are a sum of our parts. By removing some parts, we still have the overarching thing that we call "ourselves", we've just removed something that isn't vital (unless it is, in which case you'd be dead).

But then - a better definition for "you" might be "the mental processes that make you act in your own unique ways". This doesn't assume the existence of a nonphysical 'thing' that can't be demonstrated in reality, and it neatly avoids the question of what 'parts' of the body are you. "I" am not a physical object. "I" am a specific set of unique processes that are carried out by the matter of 'my body'. If the same processes were carried out by something else, it would still be me - just in a different body.

...at least, this seems to be the most logical way I can describe it. Most of the people I've discussed this with seem to either not understand the idea, or reject it on an entirely emotional basis. Oh well.

Imo, "me" is really just my mind (as in, network formed by my nervous system, especially brain) and rest of the body is really just a really sophisticated way to keep my mind (ergo, me) alive - pretty much a life support machine with a side of peripherals.
For example, if someone would lose all their limbs and get prosthetic replacements, noone would question that it is the same person - as their nervous system changed relatively little, and they still think and act mostly the same way (though probably with new experiences due to whatever accident caused said loss).
This is supported by how we actually instinctually think of things - death in legal sense is considered to be brain death, and we generally think of people in irreversible coma as pretty much dead.

We still have no idea what sleep is really for. It could be for data copying. There could be massive redundancy and duplication between neurons. Alzheimer's doesn't get really severe until much brain mass has visibly disappeared. It may be that the backups are being slowly lost but "you" can still stay functional with just the few primary copies remaining. People with Alzheimer's do sleep a lot, which might be an attempt by the brain to try to perform emergency copying to keep the memory system going, until the primary memory storage starts to fail completely, and sleeping for most of the day is no longer enough to counteract it.

This is a truly interesting video with good points, but I have to disagree. (Before I continue, know I am not very educated in these things.) I believe you over complicated things. The saying that comes to mind is, "An object is not just the sum of its parts." The human body contains trillions of cells, and all of them make us. A human cell by itself amounts to nearly nothing, but when you give it other cells to connect and react to, it can become a cat, a frog, a dog, and even you. While our parts are just cells connected together, we are the entire amount of the cells. We are the sum of our parts, but the sum of our parts are more than just the parts.

I hope that wasn't a ramble, and if you got this far reading, thank you!

If all there is to this existence ends in the physical dimension, then we cannot answer the question of why we exist...Why asks purpose...How asks function. More often than not, the language that is used amongst many scientists today is the confusion of why and how, where they will use why instead of how to describe the functions of the world. This is wrong. Science can never explain why because why steps beyond the natural (bound to the laws of the universe) and into the supernatural (beyond the laws of physics). In order for you to assume why something happened (the purpose behind something) you need to assume that there is a reason for it. If there is reason there must be a design because design is the manifestation of order for those reasons. If there is a design to the Universe there has to be a Master Designer, and the only one who claim to be such a Master Designer is an omnipotent God who created and knows everything. Why? Because without God, we would only be here by random chance. If there is no God, there is no life after death because there is nothing beyond this dimension. That's why I believe in the existence of the soul which is not bound to our physical existence. It is eternal. I believe that my conscious self was created by God because there is no explanation for my conscious self through just biological processes that are found within my brain. Animals, particularly other mammals, do have very similar structures in their brains, even go through similar thought processes as humans when working through their means to survival. Dogs can understand human commands. Gorilla's can even learn sign language, but then neither have the ability to ask questions. Only humans can, and that is what makes human clearly distinct. We are living beings. We know what it means to be. Dogs do not. Gorillas do not. They live in the moment, and they cannot interact with their memories in the way that we can, not just as a way to learn, but also to plan for the future.

1:05 "So your cells can exist without you" No they can't, Schroedingers cat a thought experiment and the double split experiment both disprove this statement.
1:08 "But you can't exist without them" Double split experiment disproves this statement.
1:11 "If we take all the cells away, then there is no you anymore" This ignores completely the upper two facts and handles human as if he was an electron (I used this particle to make it obvious related to the two experiments mentioned above) and it ignores that human is the observer and he collapses the wave function, not vice versa.
1:43 Their thought experiment is flawed simply because it was based on false premises that I disproved above. What would happen if we take away all of your cells? Nothing... you'd stay you since your existence and PERSISTENCE in that existence was never conditioned by these cells in the first place. They only allowed a particle-like material appearance to be expressed. Here it wasn't only the conclusion that was wrong but also their premises.
2:10 The fact that most of your cells and matter change within 7 years contradicts their claims and confirms the rightness of my arguments, facts and experiments I mentioned.
2:30 "So what you consider yourself is really just a snap shot" They assume we all share their opinion and consider ourselves only a group of cells or matter arranged in a certain way
3:42 How much of Henrietta is in these cells? Let me put it like this... NONE! If I were to create a for example Bobs clone with exact same arrangement of each atom and call it Jim. The matter looks EXACTLY the same (which is impossible but it's a thought experiment) . How much Bob could move Jims hand? None! Because none of Bob would be in Jim. The fact that a new type of cells derived from original cells were created has nothing to do with Henrietta! To make it even more obvious, I make cells that my kids are made of, how much of me is in my kids? NONE! Because our existence and life is not conditioned by matter. Only our physical form is. This means sadly I can't control my kids hand destroying and smashing things around our house. He has his own will that controls his own body now and I got to deal with it.
4:43 "This is kind of confusing" No it is not... you are simply wrong and your thinking is illogical and contradicts the laws of physics more precisely quantum mechanics.

At the end I'd like to clarify it even more, if you are not amazed and shocked by the duality of quantum objects (wave-particle) for example and electron... Then you did not properly understand it. Further more, look up quantum eraser experiment to realize how this man is wrong at the very end of the video about space and time and how his time perception is just non-sense.

It depends on how you define "You". Do you mean it biologically, or do you mean it psychologically?

Here is why this matters: What we as humans perceive as a "person" is the body - it's physical form. But what we perceive as personality is the mind, the consciousness, and this is the other you.

Here is an example. Imagine your mother (or another loved person) dies, you're very sad. But scientist come along with a completely new method of brain transplant. They've successfully transplanted your moms brain into a new body. Now, when you speak to this new body you know she looks different, but you know "this is my mom", cause the mind is the same, and this is what connects us to other people.
The other way around, when they would have put a completely new brain into your moms body, you'd see her body, but when you interact with her you realize "That's not my mom. It's a completely new character. New opinions, new humour, etc."

So, the question of "What are you" has to be divided into 2 aspects, cause there is the physical you, and the psychological you. Every time when we communicate, it's just brains that communicate. The entire body is just a partly automated tool to sustain the brain.

The first part of this video can be explained by elementary biology c: Life is the process of replicating Dna. Dna does it by itself, or using more complex mechanisms, like bacteria, then eukaryotic cells, then true differentiated colonies, like ooze-type moulds (oomycota, myxogastrian beings) that act more like several cities, exchanging goods and services (digestion or production of nutrients and the like) to, eventually, us. the purpose of life, in itself, is to create more life, for reasons yet unknown. Even things like feelings and love might, and some times, do have a genetic marker, so that if they are a hinderance rather than benefit when it comes to reproduction, they are slowly weeded out by the process of evolution. Now, humans are a funny exception to the rule, because through social constructs, we actively work against evolution, choosing unnatural reproductive fitness markers as a basis with which to choose a mate and replicate our own DNA.

I have no clear-cut definition for what includes "me" and what does not. If you ask a more specific question, I can usually give an answer, however. For example, a specific, newly born cell in my body is definitely a part of "me". The screen I'm looking at right now is definitely not a part of "me". But there are plenty of other examples that are on the border. For example, I'm sure there's at least one hair on my head that's fully detached from my head, but hasn't fallen away yet, and is still in the bundle of hair that is attached. Is that part of "me"? Both "yes" and "no" are valid answers.
It sucks that at some point all these questions will be answered but most likely not in our lifetimes.

Ok, I understand if I get called an idiot for this, but it's something that's been chewing me up lately. Cancer cells are immortal. Probably not in the exact way referenced in the video, but basically, they do not die off their own accord, except if they're killed artificially.

The reason why we age, is that cells, over our lifetime, start replacing themselves more slowly, weakening the immune system, carving holes in our brains, etc, etc, all things that can only lead to one thing: Death.

So. If these cancer cells don't die, if they are entirely self-sufficient and could potentially live on forever, could we too? If somehow our body was composed of cancer cells, and with this I mean cells that do not die, and we had a way to "ditch" said cells somehow, would we also be immortal?

Most of this is very easily answered. You are your brain. That's where your conscience resides. It arises from the specific way your neurons interact with each other. It's the network that's conscious, not individual cells. You are, in essence, your brain. The rest of the body is simply supplementary. Consider this: if your brain were to be surgically removed from your body and implanted into a robot body, it would still be you. However, even if only your brain were removed from your body, you would cease to exist. There is no need to get philosophical over this. Logic always provides a clear answer. And as far as I know, all our cells do have the same DNA. They get differentiated into various cells because of epigenetic markers, not mutations. As for neurons, I find it hard to believe that they could have any mutations because they do not undergo mitosis and without replication, there can be no mutation. So all in all, I found this video kind of misleading. I could be wrong.

I think the only thing that keeps you "you" is your brain. It contains all your memories, your experiences, your personality, much more oner things, and for some people, your karma. Your outside body is just your appearance. None of it actually makes you "you". Your face can be changed but you will still be "you" with plastic surgery. You can donate organs that aren't always needed, like kidneys. They will be a part of "you", until they are removed. Then they are "unclaimed" you may say, until it is put into someone else. Then it will become a part of their body, but I have no idea whether it will still have a part of you in it or when it becomes "unclaimed" it no longer has any of you in it. This could be easily disproved, but it's just my small theory. Your brain makes you "you". If it is removed from your body and somebody else's brain was put into yours and your brain was put into theirs, "you" would be taken out of "your" body and put into "somebody else's" body. When your brain gets used to the new environment, it shall then become a new "you". Your "old" body will become whoever's body you swapped with's body.

Apart from the consciousness, that it has to be included, I think that the definition itself of "you" constantly changes, same as how you change physically. So, if you replace an organ, you are still "you", but basically you changed your own definition.

For example, imagine that you are "a human, male, with brown hair etc... with a malfunctioning liver".
Now, you go to replace the liver, so the new definition would be "a human, male, with brown hair... with a new healty liver."

Entering your body system, the liver has become part of the "you" definition, and left the definition of the donor's "you".

Consciousness has to be included in the definition because it's the "vessel" that contains all the information about "you".
If you can't be a conscious being anymore, "you" does not exist anymore, and all this argument lose meaning.

Suppose the pattern you describe here is but one iteration of a larger self-similar pattern. The body as we understand it is a close knit community of individual cells. Within the cell, we find yet another, even smaller community which comprises the individual (the cell itself, in this scale). On the macro we participate in societies, not just with each other, but other organisms as well. We assume in this video that cells are devoid of consciousness. To establish this we must agree on what consciousness is. Some set the bar rather high, I think. For example, why would one presume that without the "theory of mind" a body cannot still posses a self? I do not see the correlation. "theory of mind" is a specific "idea" of what consciousness is. I do not feel it adequately describes consciousness. Intelligence, self awareness, and consciousness are not the same thing. We presume that micro organisms do not experience pain because they lack a nervous system. This may be so, but they respond to noxious stimuli with aversion or dormancy...  is  this is not a cellular reflection of what we refer to as pain? One's consciousness, in my view, is the aggregation of the communication and collaboration between your cells. Your cells themselves are sophisticated communities of molecules, communicating and collaborating. Our bodies also collaborate in social groups. Within these groups we see similar compartmentalization and specialization that we find in lesser scales. Organelle, Organ, Organization. If you absorb my precepts, one obvious question arises. If what we perceive as ourselves is the communication and collaboration between our cells, is there a potential for a sensate social consciousness to arise? An awareness of a Self within a body of bodies akin to our experience as a Self. Does it exist already? Would you know? Do your cells know you exist? Is this what ritual and culture is intended to purpose?

This video is about an academic subject called "personal identity." This is a topic under the "metaphysics" branch of philosophy. I'm amazed that the authors of this video have 0 knowledge of any of the ideas and progress within this subject in the last several centuries. They don't make any references. One quick and easy example taught in a lot of Intro Philosophy courses is John Locke's view that a memory chain constitutes your continued identity over time. Or David Hume's view that our identities do NOT continue to exist through time.

Moreover, the authors use language poorly. They constantly "beg the question" by using the word "you" too much. And the end is super unclear. What do you mean "right" and "wrong" .... those words are normative words (i.e. they concern morality, not truth). Do you mean true or false? If so, it's pretty absurd to claim that something is less true than something else. And I have no idea why that topic is introduced at the end. It's almost like you're saying "our conclusion is super unclear, but the question "what it means for something to be true" also has an unclear answer, and therefore it's "OK" for our conclusion to be super unclear".
