This is a cool video with slick presentation, however, I believe a crucial point is being missed. The main argument seems to be that we lose an enormous amount of cells that are being replaced all the time. While it is true that we are constantly losing cells and producing new cells this is not happening often and sometimes not at all with our brain. We often think that our brain gives us our identity of self and when you often hear stories of people 'not being themselves anymore', it is usually due to some sort of event/injury that caused neurological damage. This is also why brain injuries often can be fatal, our bodies are not equipped to heal neurons in the same way it heals other cells.  Also our bodies reproduce cells with stunning accuracy. when the video states how different nearby cells can be its essentially a statistically insignificant difference.

In many ways it doesn't really matter. Wondering about "what is you?" is like trying to determine when something starts becoming a heap. The analogy goes thusly: You pick up a head of rice and place it on the counter beside you. One by one you take a grain away from the heap; one grain, two grains... Now you have three grains, this other collection of grains are not yet a heap and yet they diminished the original heap, which still remains a heap. This is all a part of the idiosyncratic nature of human beings to assign labels to phenomena. There is no cut off for a heap and there is no plain cut off for consciousness or what makes you, you. Indeed the phenomena of 'you' is characterized by the ongoing presence of a singular thing, the fluidity of that thing to change itself bares no consequence to the fact that it can't still be a singular thing. In the same way a heap of 46 grains of rice is the same as a heap of 46 salt crystals.

If the definition of 'me' is a pattern, then what happens if the pattern is altered? Do I cease to be 'me'?
No. I have become convinced that the self is nothing but an illusion; a lie we tell ourselves to ignore that we are constantly being destroyed and replaced by our components.

MY BRAIN
...I think...

Ok, so if I cut off my hand, then that hand is not me. I must be the rest of the body.
But if I disconnect my head from the body, which part is me? The head, because I can still think and exist with it. If the body is destroyed, then I am the remaining head.
If I select only the brain and remove it from the rest of the head, then I am the brain and not the head. The head is discarded.

But then which part of the brain is me specifically? Am I the frontal lobe that controls thinking? No, because I can still be aware of existence without thinking about it. We can discard all the parts of the brain that control sensory input, after all there is none coming in, as well as the reptilian brain that controls movement. We can remove the cerebellum, because our memories are not us. We aren't the corpus callosum, because we can still process information without it (as long as we have everything else).

So if we can't locate where we are physically, then lets go mental. Are we our emotions? No, they just come up on their own. We can be aware of them when they arise, and we can question them. So then, are we just awareness? If we are just awareness, then we should still exist even if the matter we call "us" is destroyed. Therefore we are immortal.

Suppose the pattern you describe here is but one iteration of a larger self-similar pattern. The body as we understand it is a close knit community of individual cells. Within the cell, we find yet another, even smaller community which comprises the individual (the cell itself, in this scale). On the macro we participate in societies, not just with each other, but other organisms as well. We assume in this video that cells are devoid of consciousness. To establish this we must agree on what consciousness is. Some set the bar rather high, I think. For example, why would one presume that without the "theory of mind" a body cannot still posses a self? I do not see the correlation. "theory of mind" is a specific "idea" of what consciousness is. I do not feel it adequately describes consciousness. Intelligence, self awareness, and consciousness are not the same thing. We presume that micro organisms do not experience pain because they lack a nervous system. This may be so, but they respond to noxious stimuli with aversion or dormancy... is this is not a cellular reflection of what we refer to as pain? One's consciousness, in my view, is the aggregation of the communication and collaboration between your cells. Your cells themselves are sophisticated communities of molecules, communicating and collaborating. Our bodies also collaborate in social groups. Within these groups we see similar compartmentalization and specialization that we find in lesser scales. Organelle, Organ, Organization. If you absorb my precepts, one obvious question arises. If what we perceive as ourselves is the communication and collaboration between our cells, is there a potential for a sensate social consciousness to arise? This is just the ship of Theseus paradox recycled. The mistake on this video is that it sort of implies that "systems" are the same as a "sets". They aren't. The thing is that in science, a system is defined when there is discovered a property or pattern on something, previously defined as a mere set, that none of the elements of the set has on its own. So, consciousness is not at all a mere set of always-renewing cells. And you are not at all a mere set of always-renewing atoms.

In fact, when many patterns are discovered, new branches of science emerge, and we can better understand nature, defining the realms of physics, chemistry, biology, sociology, and so on, but not making the mistake of compartmentalizing reality.

And it is weird, to say the least, that DNA is the key to define a human individual, an ego, because of twins.

One could argue that someone's identity is deterimined by his actions, his memories and his past. But the "you" from the past is surely different that the "you" from now, considering the new cells, the growth and even the new way of percieving things. Perhaps we shouldn't be looking at the differences, but the simmilarities between the various instances of yourself. What could be that makes you from 5 years ago and the you from now the same? Maybe it is because there is no one else more similar to you that yourself from another time. Or because you maintain the first person memories of the actions of the past self. But is it theoretically possible to implant memories of someone else into you? Or to make this similarity  warped? What is the entity that we believe constitutes us in every instance of ourselves, what are the limits of the self and even what is the full concept of being and to be, are questions which might never be truly answered, due to the very nature of philosophy.

I think that the confusion that comes from the questions in this video is caused by the fact that nothing is static. Absolutely everything is constantly changing, so what we give names to is entirely arbitrary. You give a name to a baby, usually before it is born, and that baby will continue to be a living thing with that name until it dies. The problem is, that baby will never stop changing, within a couple of years it will no longer even be called a baby, but it will continue having the same name. Try not to think about it as an object, but as a story. A human is a thing, and every thing that can be observed is also a story. We observe things, but we name their stories. If you find a mountain and name it, you are naming more than you are observing. You are naming the mountain from the time it was formed until the time it no longer exists. That is not a thing, that is a story, because everything is constantly changing.

That was not an easy idea to communicate, but to sum it up, we do not name the things that we see, we name their stories. When an object changes, we see something else, but the story keeps on going. Just like a human, it will never stop changing, but its name will stay the same. The one thing that connects our weak minds to the faint idea that there is something solid in this world. Something truly static. That is not the case. Everything changes, everything ends, and nothing will ever be truly still.

In the end this question can only be answered in a philosophical way. Why? Because even the idea of being is just that: an idea. I'd say, I am or you are or a person (?) is never only a snapshot. A snapshot of my physical parts can't display some important things that constitute my identity: my history and my social environment.
One could say my history is stored in my cells but: this is just my construction of my history. I can remember things different than they happened and even different than others remember them. In the latter case the me constructed by myself differs from the me constructed by someone else. If this someone convinces me that I'm wrong, I will change my mind about that topic... will change myself. Still: if this someone doesn't convinces me, his perception of what I am will continue to exist and will be somewhat more true if his memory is more accurate than mine. But even if his perception is not true at all, it still can change the perception of the whole society about what I may be which will affect myself.
I doubt it's possible to gain all this process-information out of a snapshot.
So what am I now? Am I an Idea? Or Ideas? A continuous changing concept?

Love videos like these. Here's my take on the matter of what describes you. It is the continuous emergent entity that results from a function brain made up of all this physical matter (SOMA, anyone?). What this video is debating about, then, is more precisely asked in the following question: "Is the physical matter which comprises you, define you?" The more plausible answer is no. If we take our body and consciousness in terms of hardware and software respectively, our bodily existence no longer houses us. It instead runs us, like a computer runs a program. We are a result of this configuration of various atoms and molecules with so and so biological purpose, which all work together to project our consciousness. This differs from spirituality, however, in that the software is not your soul. It is simply the phenomenon that occurs when the various lobes of your brain are having electrical interplay amongst each other. This also differs from the 'philosophical' part of this video, where the video describes consciousness as a collective pool of entity with no clear borders, which is then housed into our bodies. There is no pool of such an entity. It doesnt exist outside of our bodies, but as a result of our bodies. Taken another way, 'you' may one day be projected by a device entirely artificial and manmade, making our bodies simple the current most advanced latticework to run us.
Doesn't this just boil down to a rigorous definition of "you"? An intuitive understanding of "you" is poorly defined and that's why we are getting so many philosophical issues.

Cells can be argued to have will and purpose. Their purpose is keeping your body functioning, or more specifically following their DNA instructions (even if those instructions mutate, and cause them to become cancer). While you can't really call this freewill, they still have means they use to achieve their objective, as ants or germs do, to varying levels of success.

Your organ in another person's body will have all your cells replaced by theirs in a few years (as you covered later).

Cell swapping: When your own body started killing itself in an immune system breakdown, your body would be shown to have a strong opinion that parts of it were not itself.

Cancer: Err, no, cancer doesn't really have a will to survive, or else it would keep its strain on the body minimal. It's just an error in DNA which causes it to go wonky with self replicating even when the body doesn't want it to. It is interesting how our body could keep itself going forever with cancer's system of upregulating telomerase, so long as we had the resources. Yet, for some reason, it doesn't.

Speculative DNA History: Show me an example of mutations that increased the complexity and size of the genome in a subject which lead to continual growth increments over generations within that species' family? You cannot. Doctors have a very low opinion of evolution, they call it cancer. Every mutation observed has been shown to reduce the genome's information, not increase it. In humans, there are approximately 100 information destroying mutations (which get passed on to your offspring) per generation. Otherwise, we could just DNA test grand parents and grand kids, and find the latter to have a larger genome than the former, so that all the life on Earth was evidence for evolution. Instead, later generations will have smaller genomes.

So, here's my take on it. Take note that this is mostly me mimicking Buddhist philosophy. The idea of anything physical being 'you' is a null concept. You are not your organs, you are not your cells, you are not your DNA, and you are not your atoms. You are your consciousness. Even if parts of your body are removed bit by bit, as long as your consciousness is still intact, you are still yourself. So if you donate your organs to someone, you did not put a part of yourself inside someone, because that organ does not hold your consciousness. You are simply gifting a complex lump of cells that used to belong to you. Similarly, once you are dead, any part of you is not you anymore.

But there's more. What we consider the 'self' is incredibly complex and dynamic. We may think we only die once, but over the course of a lifetime we die thousands, maybe millions of times. We change much more than we realize over the course of time, and what we identify as 'us' is subject to change at any moment. Either from the proccess of maturation, life experiences, trauma, enlightenment, or even changes in our biochemistry, what we consider 'us' may change even faster than our physical body can go through cells, even to the point where we may seem like an entirely different person.

Sorry if that seemed a bit rambling, I just wanted to get that out there.

"I think therefore I am" Is something we all can agree on, and if you don’t agree I will assume you don’t have a consciousness, so we should start there. If we can assume everyone has this property, then we must assume anything with a brain has it, because thinking is only the interaction between neurons, not something only humans have. Thinking otherwise is blatantly wrong. Consciousness has nothing to do with self-awareness, after all. Or at least, 'watching the movie' doesn't.

Consciousness must be something the universe allows, therefore it’s something physical. I’m honestly leaning towards the explanation that consciousness exists for any two fields interacting, or particles exchanging information, making information transfer of any level a form of consciousness, but only in the terms of 'watching a movie'. And if you scale it up to brains, then the consciousness can actually experience. This would mean everyone is technically the same exact ’observer’. By observe, I just mean the entity that is ’seeing’ and experiencing what your brain experiences.

Now, this does not mean I believe it, because there is no actual evidence, but it does make the most sense and fixes every single problem with the idea of consciousness. It fixes the cloning a brain problem. It fixes the issue that we ’die’ every few decades and are replaced, because it means we are all literally the universe, so no matter what happened to our brain we always have a continued experience. It fixes the issue of death. It fixes everything. And best of all; it isn’t metaphysical. This does have the coincidental, and horrifying, side effect that we are all everything else at once as well. Including insects. Luckily, their brains are so basic that if this were true we wouldn’t experience much through them at all.

I couldn't even begin to think of a way to test this, though. Any ideas are welcome. I would love for someone to find a major hole in this idea and destroy it utterly.

I'm with AnderZEL on this one, "you" is a maintained mental continuity of identity, an emergent property of your parts but not a quality of the parts individually. So long as you don't sever continuity you will always be you, which is one of the major issues with one-step teleportation and brain uploading. In order to properly maintain "you" between the beginning and end of either procedure, you NEED to maintain mental continuity, so at some point a single consciousness MUST be active using resources from both the old and the new. Either procedure could be done during sleep, as uncomfortable as it may sound, but the brain must remain active throughout the gradual process. The ship of Theseus is correct in assuming it is the same ship, but only if it has the same crew, the same continuity. if the boat is given to another crew, it has a new continuity, and the new ship of the old crew supplants it. Granted, you could argue the same "if a member of the crew dies and is replaced, and over the course of time all members do the same, is it still the same crew?", but I would counter and say that, so long as there was a period where it was mostly the old crew with the new member in it, this new member becomes part of what is considered the old crew and is no longer considered a new member when the next new member comes, only a younger member.

Additionally, to discuss the cell-swapping example in this video, I'd say that "you" don't move anywhere. "You" are located in one spot, and as one cell at a time is incorporated into your body, so long as it is a brain cell, it becomes a part of your mental continuity. Granted, there would be a point where eventually you would lose all your memories and only have the memories of the other person, and the same to them, so this process would likely result in personality death or at least extreme mental stress as you feel yourself lose all recollection of who "you" are, which would be horrible, but "you" itself would not move regardless.

I have recently played and finished Everybody's Gone To The Rapture, so I can't help but have it in my mind when I hear you describing life as a pattern. Indeed, in the game's story (SPOILER ALERT) a pattern/light phenomenon is discovered by a pair of astronomers and dubbed simply the Pattern. Its physics-bending and liquid-light nature aside it is upheld throughout the story that the Pattern is just that, not a thing, not a being, but a.... phenomenon that has somehow achieved sentience. It is said explicitly that it is not a 'thing', nor is it 'alive', it is "something we do not have a word for". The idea is very intriguing and it deals basically with what the video is about: is it 'alive' if it doesnt have a body? Is it sentient if it doesnt have a brain? What is the simplest, most stripped down form of life? WHAT IS LIFE?

Personally even without the game and this video to consider I was of the mind that since life cannot be assigned to a physical quantity it is an closer to an idea or pattern, a phenomenon that arises from a certain arrangement of certain elements, self preserving like an infinite feedback loop. Not much more significant or essential to universe than a rock rolling down a hill, just a natural consequence of the few simple laws that construct the world. Do we really need a meaning behind such events? We can describe how it happened, what conditions lead to what outcomes, but to say that there is a need for 'reason'? Does a rock need a reason to roll down? No, it just does. It moves from a position of high potential energy in the central gravitational field of the bigger rock it is in contact with (ie The Earth) to a position of lower potential energy. Thats just entropy, its a simple consequence of mechanics and and statistics. Life is no different.

0:40 "It has no consciousness, no will, no purpose" - can we say that? Are those well-defined enough concepts? I remember hearing a proposal that any structure of any size has a "consciousness" of some sense, from photons to galaxies - which is not as unreasonable as it first may seem, though it would obviously depend on our definition of "consciousness." Additionally, Nicky Case has recently written about emergent behavior (http://blog.ncase.me/emergent-evil/), saying that even if every single person wants to do good, the society as a whole can still function evilly - an concrete example can be seen at his and Vi Hart's the Parable of the Polygons (http://ncase.me/polygons/). It's an interesting thought about the separation between a part and the whole.

When they die (very quickly), their children will grow up 100% in the new society and most likely live in the acceptable way there so they'll be 100% part of the new society.So anyways if I continued along this line of thought, a society is that society because the people in it interact in a certain way that allows the society to move and do things "consciously". A person is that person because the cells in it interact in a certain way that allows the person to move and do things consciously. Most societies share certain ways that people interact. I hear this question pop up from time to time on youtube. I think people try to look at at an anlog question through a digital lense. I am me. I know I am me. My blood that I spill came from me, but is no longer me. The problem is that I am not a group of cells, but a person made of a group of cells. I think it is impossible to see the line between that those cells cross to form a person.

If I have a stack of metal, is that metal a car? No, it's a stack a metal. When does that stack of metal become a car? I guess one could say that when it can move and function like a car, it becomes a car. But what about before then?

Well, the key characteristic of a car is a mode of transportation. So something that looks like a car, but doesn't work like a car, can't be a car. So could we not say the same about people. A person is a person when it can perform the role of a person.

Now I know there are a TON of pitfalls with that statement. LIke is a blind, deaf, mute, quadriplegic a person. According to what I just said, no, they wouldn't be. But that would be false. But this is philosophy, not science. There currently isn't a good simple line that we can draw to say this is a person, this is no longer that person. But it is still fun to contemplate.

Personally, I don't believe that science will ever find the answer to the question of what consciousness is, because that question can never be quantified and we all know how scientists feel about things that aren't quantified. The answer must transcend science and lie somewhere in the realm of philosophy. If you think I'm wrong, please enlighten me and tell me how science can measure something as fundamentally conceptual as consciousness itself.

if you can genetically modify cancer cells, do you think that we could make immortal human beings. because what kills us is the divisions of cells and through all the dividing our cells DNA gets damaged, especially when our telomeres have been eradicated through decades of division, but if we can control our cancerous cells to stay immortal and have them only die when they are physically killed, like not getting enough nutrients or get infected, and only divide when cells need replacing, such as a cut being healed, then do you think that humans and other multicellular organisms could increase our lifespan by 10x if not actually become immortal.

So basically we are in a constant flux of life and death each moment throughout our lives existence, however long that's defined.

I'm aware I'm not the same now as I was back then nor will be in the future. I think and look differently, am physically made up of different particles, and am quite literally, completely replaced after a long enough period of time.

The question remains: What am I? What part can ever truly stay the same? People change and are shaped by their environment, their experiences, and by so many other factors unbeknownst to them, so what evidence is there that you're really you other than thinking and claiming you are?

If you think about it carefully, you've already died....




....and are reborn each and every time...
We don't really know yet is the answer.

i would like to add something:

imagine we had a super computer that could replicate how the human brain function. If we copied your brain's connections in the computer, would that still be you? It would have had the same experience and the same past as you.

Isn't who we are really just come down to our memories? If I lost all my memories irrecoverably, and started from a fresh blank slate, even though it would all be the exact same cells, that new guy would still be a different person. The guy that was "me" would be gone once all those memories are lost.

Personaly I came up with the following thought.

Imagine a program, a process, running on a machine where the program is your consciousness (actually YOU) while the machine is your brain, supported by the rest of the body.

Thus, YOU exist as long as the program is running. If it stops, YOU just disappear. You cannot copy yourself, because YOU do not exist as a material thing, unlike your body.

So even if you launch the same process somewhere else on exact machine, say on a clonned brain of yours, it will be copy of your consciousness, but not you.

If anybody reads this, I'll be glad to discuss this :)

LOVED THIS. And oh, it gets trickier. First of all, gut flora. All the microorganisms that live IN us, help us digest and are entirely individual, but we need them. "the metabolic activities performed by these bacteria resemble those of an organ, leading some to liken gut bacteria to a "forgotten" organ. It is estimated that these gut flora have around a hundred times as many genes in aggregate as there are in the human genome." says wikipedia. AND IT GETS TRICKIER. 4TH DIMENSION. If we try to be 'objective' and watch from outside of time, and life really is a giant chain of bodies coming out of other bodies, wouldn't life itself be one giant 'self' and wouldnt 'we' be just akin to its 'cells'? Living and existing to sustain the continuity of a greater body? Maybe the only reason you think of yourself as 'you' in the first place is simply evolutionary. It'd be convenient for our survival if we thought of 'our body' as a whole, not an ecossystem, but the concept of self would be no more than a tool. It's all just a pattern, parts over parts over parts, working 'cause they worked before. And there's nothing wrong with that, we just wanna think of ourselves as something 'more' 'cause of "free will", "consciousness" and all these undefinable buzzwords.

I don't really consider my consciousness being me and nothing else to be a philosophical problem at all really. The cells of your body make up your physical form yes, but we also recognise that removing and replacing any part of your body has no real impact on you as a person. It doesn't change you, your reaction to having an arm replaced may change you but that is purely psychological.

The brain is the only aspect that supports your consciousness. Every part of you could be removed with the exception of the brain and you would still be you. Remove the brain and you would be dead. If scientists managed to understand what consciousness was, it could be moved out of your organic body and into a computer that would allow you to exist not just outside of your original form entirely, but could also make you immortal.

As we understand it, the brain is fundamental to human consciousness. However if a synthetic brain was built and it could be hooked up to your own, allowing for transference, that would do the trick too, you may not need to understand anymore about consciousness than we already do.

So. Here we are again. Painting pictures on a wall. I can’t decide what to write about, so I’ll just write what comes to mind. It won’t be perfect, and it won’t be eloquent, but at least, it’ll be. And isn’t that what matters? Being? Thoughts come into and pass through your mind like water passes through a river, forgotten in the sea of time. A vessel can only hold so little of it, but a portion of a fraction of a miniscule percentage, and only for so much time before it spills or crumbles to dust. But for a moment, we may behold it, and perhaps for a time it will remain, so that it is given a life it did not choose. The great flow never stops, but occasionally, it floods. The rains feed the sea in a cycle that never ends, except in death, but is death the end, or merely another beginning? Are beginnings ends of times of oblivion or are they just a human effort to put starts and ends in a journey where nothing applies. And what of the erosion, of the crumbling of the banks against the unrelenting power of the stream? I don’t know. I don’t think I’ll ever know. But I don’t ask for the answer, I ask for the question.
Plans. Plans I’ll never follow. Goals I won’t achieve. Dreams that don’t come to fruition. Why do I do it all? Because effort matters. Time matters. And even if I don’t get where I want to be, at least I’ll never be where I was, again. Maybe lower, but ropes and ladders will stay to climb. Do I burn them, so that I never have to drown? No. Falling is inevitable. Failing is inevitable. Pain is inevitable. Suffering, is optional.
Choices. Decisions. Will. Is identity the purity of action and intention? What hidden chains do I pull against? What subtle knife is aimed at my throat? The conscious and subconscious fight when it is better for them in harmony for neither can comprehend the concept of compromise and neither would trade an opportunity to do what they want. The blade is mine, and the chains are stitched of my own sinew and bone. To break them, is to break me.
Freedom. Power. Perhaps I should be broken. Remade, forged into something different, better, more. Why am I so attached to the concept of reality and myself when they are ever changing but may never be destroyed?

I'm going to say that my belief is that "you" are the conscious part of you. You are the amalgamation of billions of cells. As soon as you lose that intangible part, you're no longer you. This is why some people who have brain damage are said to be "no longer themself".

I would say that your "consciousness" is based on the electrical signals (synapses) sent between neurons in the brain in certain orders. With this theory, you could never completely clone a person's brain. Sure you could scan their brain matter down to the atomic level and recreate it into an identical brain, but you are you because of how those signals specifically interact with the other neurons to recall "memories".

I'm not in this field of study at all, but now I'm starting to take an interest in these theories. I'd love to see counter arguments for what I've proposed as well (especially considering that I know next to nothing about this). :D

I think it's more of a philosophical question than anything else, let's set the following case: a man acquires some kind of disease that renders most of his body useless, so he replaces most organs and limbs (except his brain and head) with robotic parts, in science/ science-fiction this is called a cyborg. Is this being still a human? He still experiences sadness, anger, joy and other basic human emotions, or we are then to define a new "species" called cyborgs that are not human? If in the future, we could integrate an AI to a human brain/body, would this still be a person? Or if theoretically, an AI in the future behaves just like a person and has a bio-mechanical body, could this being be considered a human? I think that technology will lead us to redefine what we call humans and make us see that it could be an obsolete definition.

I am somewhat disappointed (but still, magnificent work!) that there has been little cognitive science in the making of this. CGP-G's video does somewhat alright in this regard but the fact is that you're not necessarily "two". You're always your present neural firings at any time; the illustration for this neural aspect in the "patterns of snapshots" would've tied ends together far better from the scientific perspective, since the aspect of ever-changing cells was mentioned too.
And also, you do not know whether cells have or do not have either consciousness or purpose. Information Integration Theory (IIT) assumes that sentience is the result of complexity of organized systems of information, and that protoconsciousness may be a property of any smallest units (particles). Thus, cells may be conscious, but virtually zero, yet still not zero. And we do not ultimately know the entirety of the process of nature and evolution, which may as well be "purposeful" (create life), thus cells also having purpose on their terms almost completely unbeknownst to them.

Nah. If you take away my cells, you take away my body. I like my body as a tool, a fun machine to play with, but that's about all there is to it. I control my tools, but I am not the tools that I use.
If people weren't so attached to their body and their identification with it, they wouldn't even come up with such nonsense as "I am this body".
Does using a hammer turn you into a hammer? No. Why should using a body be any different?
Claiming that cells have no consciousness is a pretty grand statement as well.
Have you ever talked to a cell? Probably not. But is that because cells can not talk, or because you don't understand their language?
And when we're speaking of language. What even makes you assume that you are actually communicating with people? That's just a belief. A pretty useful belief that makes navigating this delusional world a lot simpler, but a belief nonetheless.
Either everything is conscious, or nothing is.
You can only use stuff to change it into something else. Giving it different names and labels doesn't change the fact that everything is fundamentally the same.
Humans are quite staggeringly unconscious though. When you learn something, you eventually stop paying attention to all the details in the process of application your self-created knowledge and tools. Since everything is only differing in appearance, it only takes a small stretch to realize that you are simply unaware of all the other nonsense that you have "learned" (created for yourself) previously, such as the universe.
Oh, but that's insane! There's no way that could be true! - Okay, what did you have for dinner on May the 30th 2000? Don't remember?
Why then would you assume that you remember what you were on about before you have grown so attached to the body that you have now identified yourself with?
The body is just a hard drive of genetic information, the brain is just a computer with some software that allows you to easily use your body and an extra hard drive that stores what you refer to as memories.
Both of these change all the time, but the actual user of those tools does not.
The illusion of an "outside world" makes the idea of a "physical self" a pretty convincing delusion though. Especially if you give a lot of authority to it when it comes to deciding what reality actually is.

The question of what is "me" only makes sense when you define yourself in relation to something else. If you don't make that jump there simply is neither question nor answer. There's nothing to know beyond what you choose to know.

Some people called you God, some called you empty space. But all of those are just further delusions that can only serve to distract you from yourself or to entertain you. Which of these two it is at any given time, is a free choice made by yourself.

I was me when I started this comment and I am me when I finish it, just as you are you when you read it and still you when you've finished. Our thoughts are what makes us, not our bodies. Our bodies are merely an engine for our thoughts. If we developed the technology to transfer a brain to a computer without loss of memory or ability to control a human body, then gave that computer control of a synthetic version of a human body, the brain would still be the person it was before, despite having no part of the organic organism, it still had the memories and the thoughts in a constant stream. The only reason we can't replace our body parts forever and be essentially immortal, sparing disease, is that we can't replace our brains, and therefore when they degenerate we can no longer be called ourselves, and we are dead.

I am entirely immaterial, even though the body i call my own is not.

So in my opinion the question of what "you" is can't just be answered with biology. Because "you" consists not only of your body, but also there is your character formed by your experiences in life, you environment and so on. The information that creates your character is stored in your brain cells and as far as I know they aren't renewable. So I personally would say as soon as you remove any part of the brain that contains brain cells you aren't any longer "you". Because you can form your body by doing sports, you can get a gender change or you can get a robot hand, but in the end, the brain with your behavior and character remains the same. So I would say the "you" isn't defined by your body, it's defined by your way of existing.
I hope you understand what I am talking about.

First of all, I can't express how I love your simplified animation style, and how you turn basic geometric shapes into something so recognisable! (Though sometimes I have a hard time reading the text on the screen due to the fast transitions...). Also the lovely background music that connects beautifully with the graphics, and the intro was more fluid than ever.

Secondly, in the matter of the content of the video, I think that humans developed definitions to objects in certain orders of magnitude, without knowing that you can divide them into smaller objects which can be defined otherwise. Because of that, when someone say "me" every person understands that "me" refers to the whole person who is speaking and not to the cells that make him.

In other words, because of the history of the human knowledge and its effects on the human language, you cannot simply refer to a whole human as the cells that make that person. This means that when you start messing with the cells of the person's body, every definition in a larger order of magnitude becomes irrelevant because that definition is more abstract.

So besides being a nice question that makes a person think about the question, it's not that difficult, because once you understand that in larger magnitudes definitions are more abstract than smaller ones, you realise that this question is a bit silly and not that smart after all.

I thought you guys might touch on consciousness in this one. Personally, I believe consciousness exists on a spectrum: not either conscious or not but rather how conscious. With this model I predict the development of detailed language is a major breakthrough in quality or degree of consciousness. With language we could structure our thoughts and share them more easily, as well as ask questions. That being said, I don't believe any individual cell can possess consciousness. From my experience, consciousness arrives from a complex network of millions of cells working together. Thus, consciousness is an emergent property of any sufficiently complex information processing system.

I'm not a thing; not an object or a collection of cells. I'm a process, an ongoing collection of more or less coherent matter (at least after I've had my morning tea) that holds itself together and self-sustains. On one level, that's me.

On another level, I'm still a process, but I'm the process of ongoing activity in my brain. This process can be modified by chemicals, whether those produced by my own body or those I choose to insert into the process from the outside. The process can even be split, broken from one process into two, by cutting the bridge between the two hemisphere's of the brain. At this level, every part of my body could be replaced, as long as my brain was left intact, and I would still be me.

More precisely, sleep to me is more analogous to standby than shutdown, since all the data in your RAM isn't cleared when you fall asleep.
